What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned an incredible amount about the Korean diaspora, tattooing in the United States and Korea, and about myself as a diaspora subject. Mimi sent me readings on things like affect theory and Adorno's aesthetics that I would never have read otherwise. Professor Helen Siu also introduced me to Weber and Appadurai, which were instrumental to this paper.

Writing my thesis helped synthesize what I learned over the course of my time at Yale. Using my language skills, history knowledge and understanding of Chinese politics in one assignment was deeply rewarding.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's a senior thesis. There's not much else that can be said. Professor Rosenbluth and Mimi were both very helpful guiding me, with the former pointing me to Professors Helen Siu and Yukiko Koga, without whom I would have struggled a lot.
This course was a very good experience to learn about a subject and topic that I am interested in! Definitely choose something that interests you! This freedom to pick is awesome.
The thesis was an amazing learning process

This was such a great way to explore topics that I have been interested in and I learned various ways to engage with Japanese primary sources! 
I definitely didn't feel much support. I think having regular meetings with advisors as well as larger meetings with other students in the major would have been very helpful. I know that other majors and programs do this, so I would consider having that.
Professor Mattingly was an incredible resource and was very generous with his time. His unrivaled knowledge of the subject matter was indispensable to my being able to write my thesis.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is very rewarding to be able to write on something you have a personal interest in and to see the fruits of your labor at the end of the process.
Yes! Pick a topic that you find interesting and learn about it.
Yes! It builds on everything you learned at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Email. I was prepared to write about Mimi Yiengpruksawan, since she's my advisor, but with both of them I primarily corresponded in email and some 1:1 Zooms during office hours.
Senior essay so met with advisor on zoom
